Description: Scaraboid in Egyptian blue; back in form of Black African head crudely cut out, with hair indicated by cross-hatched diamonds, facial features very small and simplified; flat in profile; underside incised with winged griffin seated to right; longitudinally pierced; blue paste with hard, coarse texture of bright blue colour; badly rubbed.
Curator's comments: Winged mythological creatures are a very popular motif in the Scarab Factory (on this production, see Webb forthcoming). This Egyptian Blue scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially in Carthage, Kerkouan, Sicily and Gibraltar, but also in Greece, Cyprus and Rhodes (Gorton 1996, 118-121, type XXXIII, see especially C8 for this piece). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 133)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 120, Type XXXIII C8)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OF.01) (phase 3)
